text: Amazon
Quicksight now supports Fine-grained Visual Embedding allowing you to display
individual visuals from Quicksight dashboards
in your application, portals, and sites.
In this demo,
we'll see how easy it is to accomplish this so you can enhance
your applications and provide insights to your end users where they are right away.
To get started,
let's navigate to the Quicksight console and take a look at our visuals.
The dashboard we'll be using for this
demo is based on the one in QuickSight's getting started tutorial,
which you can set up if you'd like to follow along.
The account has also been configured already to enable public embedding, and you can
visit the link shown below for instructions
on completing these prerequisites in your account.
These two visuals are from the tutorial, but we've
created a few additional ones for some variety.
Let's first embed this pie chart on a private, internal page
meant only for other authorized users with access to this QuickSight dashboard.
Before we proceed though,
we need to explicitly allow the site's domain for embedding,
which is as easy as opening the QuickSight management settings
and adding the domain on the domains and embedding page.
Now, back at the dashboard, we just click "Embed visual", and
then "COPY CODE" to get the necessary embedding iframe code.
Then ,we simply paste the copied iframe code to our site, and the
individual visual will appear separately from the
dashboard for authorized viewers to interact with.
If an authorized viewer visits it, but isn't already logged into QuickSight,
they'll be prompted to do so.
But what if we want to embed visuals in a public blog post for anyone to see,
not just internal users?
First, we share the dashboard publicly by clicking "Share dashboard",
selecting
"Anyone on the Internet", and then confirming.
With the dashboard being made public,
we can now view the embedded pie chart on the sample page from earlier,
even though we've just logged out of QuickSight.
Finally,
we can use the QuickSight API to programmatically
generate preauthorized, one-time use, limited lifetime embed
URLs
for both registered and anonymous users.
This helps keep our data secure when embedding
in SaaS applications where we don't want our data
to be public, but we don't want individual
end users to have direct access to QuickSight
either.
The QuickSight API is available through the AWS
CLI as well as programming languages like Python,
JavaScript, and others with AWS SDK support.
To learn more about Fine-grained Visual Embedding and
other embedded analytics features powered by Amazon QuickSight,
please visit the link shown below.
